GER100Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription:
This is the language course to take if you have had no previous experience of the German language. The emphasis is on comprehension, speaking, reading, writing, vocabulary and basic grammar. This course can be counted towards all programs in German.

Note: Students with any previous knowledge of German are REQUIRED to take a placement test offered at the department.
GER100Y1-Y-20209.exclusion: Senior high school German or equivalent. Note: Students with any previous knowledge of German are required to take a placement test offered at the department.
GER100Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is for students with no prior background in German. Any student with ANY background or knowledge of the German languages is REQUIRED to take a written placement test, which takes thirty minutes. It takes place at the German Department, 50 St. Joseph St., (at Bay St./wing of St. Basil's Church), Odette Hall, 3rd Floor. Office is room 322. To arrange for a placement test, please email gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca
GER100Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER101H1-S-20209.courseDescription: This course is intended for students with some prior knowledge of German. It is equivalent to the Spring Term of GER100Y1. The emphasis is on comprehension, speaking, reading, writing, vocabulary and basic grammar.
GER101H1-S-20209.exclusion: Senior high school German or equivalent. GER100Y1.
GER101H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course joins GER 100Y1 in the Spring term. Students must be placed at this level after completion of a placement test. Contact Gayle Grisdale @ gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca to arrange one.
GER101H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER102Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is for Graduate Students wishing to take Introduction to German I. You must get your Add/Drop dates from from your home department signed and brought to the German Department for signature. Email the German Department if you have any questions at gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca.
GER102Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER150H1-S-20209.courseDescription: This course taught in English is intended for students who are unfamiliar with German culture. It examines historical, political and cultural developments in Germany from about 1871 to the present focusing on literary and non-literary texts. (Note: This course is required for the major and specialist program; it should be taken within the first two years.)
GER150H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is taught in English. You are required to take a tutorial if you are registered for this course.
GER150H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

GER194H1-F-20209.courseTitle: The Age of Reason and the New World (E)
GER194H1-F-20209.courseDescription: In this course we will examine the growing awareness of the strange new world beyond Europe in the so-called Age of Reason. How did writers respond to the challenges of radically different cultures? What did their way of life and their world view mean for a Europe that placed reason above all other human qualities? How did the fact of slavery and exploitation change the way they viewed the "New World"? What did this encounter mean for growing preoccupations with common humanity? We will read a number of classic texts from the European Enlightenment with an eye to these and other questions. All readings and class discussions will be in English. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
GER194H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER195H1-S-20209.courseDescription: Cities have been described as places of desire and places of fear. They pulse with life, bringing together people from different class, gender, and ethnic backgrounds, simultaneously giving rise to a sense of freedom and oppression, a sense of belonging and alienation. This course will explore the city as a physical reality that shapes our lives, but is also a projection of our deepest imaginings. Through readings of philosophical and sociological texts by influential theorists of the city, we will consider various ancient and modern conceptions of urban space and subjectivity. Alongside these theoretical readings, we will also examine literary and filmic representations of the city as a space of desire, memory and power. All readings and class discussions are in English. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
GER195H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is taught in English.
GER195H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

GER200Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: This course continues the work done in GER100Y1 / GER101H1. It further expands on basic grammar and vocabulary, practice in comprehension, composition, and conversation.
GER200Y1-Y-20209.prerequisite: GER100Y1/GER101H1 or German placement test, Senior high school German or equivalent
GER200Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Prerequisite: GER100Y1 or GER101H or placement by department. Note: Any student with ANY background or knowledge of the German languages is REQUIRED to take a written placement test, which takes thirty minutes. It takes place at the German Department, 50 St. Joseph St., (at Bay St./wing of St. Basil's Church), Odette Hall, 3rd Floor. Office is room 322. To arrange for a placement test, please email gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca
GER200Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER201H1-S-20209.courseDescription: This course is equivalent to the Spring Term of GER200Y1. It further expands on basic grammar and vocabulary, practice in comprehension, composition, and conversation. The Department reserves the right to place students in the appropriate language course on the 200- and 300 levels.
GER201H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course joins GER 200Y1 in the Spring term. Students must be placed at this level after completion of a placement test. Contact Gayle Grisdale @ gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca to arrange one.
GER201H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions:
The course will be based on the HyFlex model or the Flipped Classroom model.
--HyFlex model: Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance) and tutorials are delivered per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and will not have to purchase external software; access to a computer equipped with a microphone and a camera is required.
--Flipped Classroom model: Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Tutorials are delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and will not have to purchase external software; access to a computer equipped with a microphone and a camera is required.

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

GER205H1-S-20209.courseDescription:
This course offers a transition from the language courses to the topic courses on the 300-level. It introduces students to German literature and provides them with working methods and analytical tools relevant for the study of German literary texts in the original German.

Note: This course is required for the major and specialist program
GER205H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is taught in German. It is a prerequisite for all 3rd-year literature courses and a requirement for German majors and specialists.
GER205H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

GER260Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: This course introduces Yiddish language, literature, music, theater, and cinema through interactive multi-media seminars, designed to build proficiency in reading, writing and comprehending. No prior knowledge of Yiddish is required.
GER260Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This is a language course for absolute beginners. If you have any pre-knowledge of Yiddish, please contact the German Department.
GER260Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER275H1-F-20209.courseDescription: This is an introductory course to the thought of Karl Marx, Friedrich Nietzsche, and Sigmund Freud and their pioneering contributions to the understanding of the individual and society in modernity. Readings include selections from writings of the early Marx, the Communist Manifesto, and Capital, Nietzsche's critique of culture, academe, and nationalism, and Freud's theory of culture, his views on the psychopathology of everyday life, on the meaning of dreams, symptoms, the return of the repressed, and what it might mean to live in a free society.
GER275H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered per meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER290H1-S-20209.courseDescription: The movement of cultural products, material goods, capital, people, ideas, and information across national borders has resulted in a new quality of global interdependency. The course explores the contemporary character of globalization patterns and problems as they bear on German-speaking contexts. Readings in globalization history and theory.
GER290H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER300Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: Continuing the work done in GER100Y1 and GER200Y1, this course offers German at the intermediate level focusing on extension of vocabulary, specific problems of grammar, essay-writing, reading and conversation. The Department reserves the right to place students in the appropriate course in the series GER200Y1 and GER300Y1.
GER300Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Prerequisite: GER200Y1 or GER201H or placement by department. Note: Any student with ANY background or knowledge of the German languages is REQUIRED to take a written placement test, which takes thirty minutes. It takes place at the German Department, 50 St. Joseph St., (at Bay St./wing of St. Basil's Church), Odette Hall, 3rd Floor. Office is room 322. To arrange for a placement test, please email gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca
GER300Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER301H1-S-20209.courseDescription: This course is equivalent to the Spring Term of GER300Y1. It further expands on basic grammar and vocabulary, practice in comprehension, composition, and conversation at the intermediate level. The Department reserves the right to place students in the appropriate language course on the 200- and 300 levels.
GER301H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course joins GER 300Y1 in the Spring term. Students must be placed at this level after completion of a placement test. Contact Gayle Grisdale @ gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca to arrange one.

--HyFlex model: Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance) and tutorials are delivered per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and will not have to purchase external software; access to a computer equipped with a microphone and a camera is required.
--Flipped Classroom model: Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Tutorials are delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and will not have to purchase external software; access to a computer equipped with a microphone and a camera is required.

GER305H1-F-20209.courseDescription: Building on the work of GER205H1, this course offers a survey of German literature and culture from the eighteenth to the twentieth century. Within a chronological framework, students read and analyze excerpts from representative works of major German writers. (Note: This course is required for the major and specialist program, and should be taken concurrently with GER300Y1.)
GER305H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Prerequisite: GER205H1 (or permission by department). This course is taught in German. It is a prerequisite for all 3rd-year literature courses and a requirement for German majors and specialists.
GER305H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER310H1-F-20209.courseDescription: This course focuses on contemporary German culture as expressed through a variety of media. It approaches Germany and Germany's position within Europe and the world mainly (but not exclusively) through non-literary texts.
GER310H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER321H1-S-20209.courseDescription: This course focuses on German authors of the nineteenth century. Literary, political and philosophical texts are analyzed as a discussion of political uprisings, the industrial revolution and the emergence of German nationalism.
GER321H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is taught in German. Prerequisite: GER205H1 (or permission by department).
GER321H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

GER322H1-S-20209.courseDescription: Franz Kafka's texts are read in the literary, historical, and philosophical context of fin-de-sicle Prague and central Europe.
GER322H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is taught in German. Prerequisite: GER205H1 (or permission by department).
GER322H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

GER323H1-F-20209.courseDescription: Focusing roughly on the period from 1918 to 1945, this course examines literary and artistic movements like Dada, Bauhaus, the Golden Age in German film in the decades between World War I and Nazism.
GER323H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is taught in German. Prerequisite: GER205H1 (or permission by department).
GER323H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: It is expected that students have a computer with a microphone for this course, and software which allows them to watch lecture recordings and to produce their own voice recordings. Office/contact hours will be offered by appointment.

GER326H1-S-20209.courseDescription: An examination of post-World War II German literature and culture from Zero Hour through to present-day debates about the Holocaust and its memorialization within a German context.
GER326H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is taught in German. Prerequisite: GER205H1 (or permission by department).
GER326H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

GER332H1-F-20209.courseDescription: An analysis of the artistic confrontation with deviance, madness, and outsiders. The course covers expressions of this confrontation in a variety of genres.
GER332H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is taught in German. Prerequisite: GER205H1 (or permission by department).
GER332H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: It is expected that students have a computer with a microphone for this course, and software which allows them to watch lecture recordings and to produce their own voice recordings. Office/contact hours will be offered by appointment.

GER360H1-F-20209.courseDescription: The course conducted in Yiddish offers a review of basic grammar, stylistics, study of short literary texts.
GER360H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER361H1-F-20209.courseDescription: An overview of the major figures and tendencies in modern Yiddish literature and culture from the beginning of the 19th century to the present. Readings (in English) of modern Yiddish prose, poetry, drama and cinema.
GER361H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER370H1-F-20209.courseDescription:
This course provides students with a working knowledge of German business culture that allows them to navigate the German workplace. The main focus is to deepen students knowledge of business concepts.

Note: This course is required for the minor program in Business German
GER370H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online. Students need access to Quercus and collaboration software (such as BB Collaborate, MS Teams or Zoom).

GER372H1-S-20209.courseDescription: This course offers an intensive development of the linguistic skills needed in the context of business transactions and management in German-speaking countries. Through materials from various sources, students develop oral and written skills for competence in German business communication as well as cross-cultural awareness.
GER372H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is taught in German. Prerequisite: GER370H1.
GER372H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

GER391H1-F-20209.courseTitle: iPRAKTIKUM Experiential Learning and Internationalization Internship
GER391H1-F-20209.courseDescription: The course provides curricular support for a variety of work and community-engaged, experiential learning placements in the GTA and in German-speaking countries. The placements are designed to deepen linguistic, cultural, and analytical skills acquired in the classroom in work-related environments, create an awareness of the translatability of academic knowledge to other contexts, promote global competency, and foster links to the community. The number of weekly hours spent in the field, the scope of learning objectives, and the nature of reflective activities are determined on an individual basis in consultation with the host institution, the German Department, and other units in which the student is pursuing a program degree (as required). In addition to successfully achieving the formulated learning goals, students must complete assignments such as eJournals and research papers as well as participate in peer-to-peer reporting and post-placement interviews.
GER391H1-F-20209.prerequisite: GER100Y1 and GER200Y1 or consent of department (equivalent proficiency level B1)
GER391H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions:
iPractikum - Experimental Leaning Internationalization. 

Check at German Department

GER400H1-F-20209.courseDescription: This is a course for advanced learners of German reviewing complex features of the language and introducing them to aspects of German stylistics. The emphasis lies on oral and written communication.
GER400H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Prerequisite: GER300Y1 or GER301H or placement by department. Note: Any student with ANY background or knowledge of the German languages is REQUIRED to take a written placement test, which takes thirty minutes. It takes place at the German Department, 50 St. Joseph St., (at Bay St./wing of St. Basil's Church), Odette Hall, 3rd Floor. Office is room 322. To arrange for a placement test, please email gayle.grisdale@utoronto.ca

GER410H1-F-20209.courseDescription: This course taught in English offers an examination of key moments and themes in German intellectual history from the Enlightenment to the present.
GER410H1-F-20209.prerequisite: Advanced status: permission of the department
GER410H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: Classes will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students must be present online at the listed meeting time. The lectures/classes will not be available as recordings; no asynchronous option is offered. Students need the ability to view PDFs or PowerPoint slides and to access online library resources, Quercus tools, and collaboration software (including BB Collaborate, MS Teams, and Zoom). It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

GER426H1-S-20209.courseDescription: This course offers an introduction to the language, literature and culture of Medieval Germany. The reading and translation of exemplary medieval German texts will introduce students to Middle High German and provide an insight into epochal concepts like courtly love and chivalry as well as courtly and monastic designs of identity.

GER431H1-S-20209.courseDescription: An open course which explores specific aspects of Germanic Studies.
GER431H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: This course is taught in German. Prerequisite: GER305H1 or permission by department.
GER431H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions:
The course will be based on the HyFlex model or the Flipped Classroom model.
--HyFlex model: Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance) and tutorials are delivered per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and will not have to purchase external software; access to a computer equipped with a microphone and a camera is required.
--Flipped Classroom model: Lectures will be pre-recorded, and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Tutorials are delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need access to Quercus and will not have to purchase external software; access to a computer equipped with a microphone and a camera is required.

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

GER460H1-S-20209.courseDescription: This course conducted entirely in Yiddish focuses on advanced reading, writing, vocabulary and conversation, the study of poetry, short fiction, and memoir literature by leading authors. Selected advanced grammatical topics are presented in conjunction with the study of texts.
GER460H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.
